sector_overview.headline: NAICS 51 is the AI economy's self-referential core: the sector PRODUCING AI tools is also the sector most DISRUPTED by them. Internal bifurcation is the defining dynamic -- AI infrastructure sub-sectors (518, 519) are accelerating at 20-30% growth while content creation sub-sectors (512, 516) are collapsing at -6% to -14%. Software publishing (5132) faces existential pressure as AI code generation reaches 82% developer adoption. The sector's $155K average wage creates the single largest Baumol cure opportunity per-worker in the economy. This is not a sector 'being disrupted by AI' -- it IS the disruption engine, eating itself from the inside.

sector_economics.sector_revenue_estimate: $1.8T+ (US information sector including software, cloud, media, telecom)
sector_economics.notes: Highest average pay of any 2-digit sector after Finance (52). Employment contracting (-2.33%) while wages surge (+6.67%) = classic Baumol signature. But unlike healthcare or education where Baumol cure releases stored energy, information sector IS the cure agent for other sectors. The self-referential loop creates unique dynamics.

sector_overview.key_hypothesis_validated: The sector screener hypothesis -- 'Information sector is bifurcating: AI infrastructure accelerating while content creation contracts' -- is CONFIRMED and STRONGER than hypothesized. The bifurcation is not just growth-vs-decline but a fundamental restructuring of what 'information work' means. Infrastructure (compute, hosting, data) grows as substrate; content creation (film, publishing, journalism) collapses as AI automates the routine-cognitive middle; software publishing faces existential redefinition as AI shifts the boundary between 'product' and 'service'.
phase_evidence: Motion picture employment -13.91% (QCEW) to -24.1% (v3-6 signals) -- accelerating decline
Internet publishing employment -6.36% despite +16.4% wage growth -- Baumol signature at extreme
Cloud infrastructure employment +4.08% with $600B+ hyperscaler capex planned 2026
AI code assistant market growing from $7.4B (2025) to $24B (2030) at 26.6% CAGR
Washington Post laid off 1/3 of staff (Feb 2026) -- institutional media collapse accelerating
Google search market ratio to AI search halved from 10:1 to 4.7:1 in 12 months
Gartner: traditional search volume drops 25% by 2026
Data center capex approaching $1T globally in 2026
Video game industry: 1/3 of US developers laid off in 2025

sub_sector_analysis.name: Computing Infrastructure Providers, Data Processing, Web Hosting

current_state.market_dynamics: AI workload demand is driving the largest infrastructure buildout since the internet itself. Global cloud infrastructure market at $752B (2025), projected $2.39T by 2030. AWS ($100B+ annual revenue), Azure (31% YoY growth), Google Cloud ($50B run-rate, first profitable year 2025). Hyperscalers spending ~$700B combined capex in 2026, with $450B going to AI infrastructure specifically.
current_state.employment_trajectory: Growing but QUALITY is shifting. Traditional data center operations (facilities management, hardware racking) being automated. New roles: AI infrastructure engineers, GPU cluster optimization, cooling system specialists, power grid negotiators. Employment growth is in high-skill technical roles, not operational ones.
key_data_points: Cloud market: AWS 31%, Azure 25%, Google Cloud 11% -- Big Three hold 67%
Data center capex approaching $1T globally in 2026
IEA: data center electricity doubling to 945 TWh by 2030
US data center occupancy projected 95%+ by late 2026 -- physical capacity crisis
PJM capacity auction: $16.4B (3rd consecutive record), data centers 63% of price increase
2,600 GW in grid interconnection queue, 5+ year wait -- binding constraint on AI scaling
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Late installation, approaching deployment. Capital is FLOODING in ($600B+ hyperscaler capex) but physical constraints (power, cooling, land) are emerging as binding. Jevons Paradox in action: cheaper compute drives MORE demand, not less. The infrastructure layer is the ONLY part of the information sector where physical scarcity creates durable moats.
current_state.baumol_dynamics: Unlike other information sub-sectors, computing infrastructure has PHYSICAL constraints that limit Baumol cure dynamics. You cannot 10x a data center's capacity with AI -- you need physical land, power, cooling. This creates Baumol Premium characteristics within an otherwise Baumol Cure sector.
current_state.transformation_summary: Growth accelerating but shifting from 'build more capacity' to 'optimize what exists + build AI-native infrastructure.' The pivot from AI training clusters to inference infrastructure (closer to users, lower latency) is the 2026 inflection. Edge computing and private 5G networks create new infrastructure layer below hyperscale cloud.

year_by_year_projection.2026: Capex peaks for training clusters. Inference infrastructure buildout begins at scale. Physical capacity crisis (95%+ occupancy). Power constraints force hyperscalers into nuclear/solar PPAs. Private 5G network market hits $5.7B.
year_by_year_projection.2027: First wave of AI-native data centers operational (designed for inference, not training). Edge computing proliferates. Cooling innovation (zero-water, immersion) becomes competitive advantage. Oracle and neoclouds (CoreWeave, Lambda) gain 5-8% combined share.
year_by_year_projection.2028: Grid interconnection queue begins clearing for 2023-2024 applications. New nuclear (SMR) facilities begin contributing. Data center REITs split into AI-optimized vs legacy tiers with 3-5x valuation gap.
year_by_year_projection.2029: AI inference at edge becomes standard. Hyperscaler margin pressure as commodity inference competes with premium. Private cloud for AI workloads becomes enterprise default for regulated industries.
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: Data center electricity at 6-12% of US grid (IEA). Industry consolidation: Big Three + 2-3 AI-native clouds dominate. Legacy hosting/colocation either acquired or marginalized. Employment flat despite 3x revenue -- automation of operations.

sub_sector_analysis.name: Web Search Portals, Libraries, Archives, and Other Information Services

current_state.market_dynamics: The highest Baumol score (3.72) of any sub-sector in the analysis -- $270K average pay with declining employment. This is the AI search revolution in real-time. Google's search monopoly is under pressure: AI search platforms grew 721% in monthly traffic, capturing 8% of search market by mid-2025. The ratio of Google users to AI search users halved from 10:1 to 4.7:1 in 12 months. Gartner predicts 25% traditional search volume drop by 2026.
current_state.employment_trajectory: Contracting at high wages. The classic 'too expensive to maintain, too complex to automate fully' squeeze. Web search portal employment declining as AI answers replace web crawling/indexing/serving. But AI research roles within these companies (Google DeepMind, Meta FAIR) are growing at premium wages, driving the $270K average higher.
key_data_points: Google search: 89.56% global share but ratio to AI search users halved in 12 months (10:1 -> 4.7:1)
AI Overviews advertising: 1% of Google search ad revenue in 2025, projected 3% in 2026, 6-7% in 2027
ChatGPT 810M MAU, but share of AI chatbot traffic fell 87% -> 68%; Gemini rose 5% -> 18%
Alphabet announced $180B 2026 spending plan (biggest ever) -- all-in on AI
Baumol score 3.72: highest in NAICS 51, wages growing fastest while employment declines
Data/analytics companies within 519 growing at 15-20% as AI creates demand for training data and data infrastructure
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Active creative destruction. The entire 'web search portal' business model is being Schumpeter-destroyed by AI chat/search. Google is attempting sustaining innovation (AI Overviews) but the business model transition from 'show 10 blue links with ads' to 'give one AI answer' threatens the ad-revenue model structurally. This is Christensen's Innovator's Dilemma in real-time: Google cannot fully cannibalize search ads to serve AI answers.
current_state.baumol_dynamics: Extreme Baumol Cure dynamics. $270K average wages with employment declining = massive stored Baumol energy. But unlike healthcare or legal where AI cures cost disease, here AI is destroying the REVENUE model, not just compressing costs. This is Baumol Destruction, not Baumol Cure -- the sector gets cheaper AND the revenue disappears.
current_state.transformation_summary: Web search portals face existential transformation as AI answers replace web indexing. Data services within 519 are the counter-story: AI creates insatiable demand for training data, synthetic data, data labeling, and data infrastructure. The sub-sector splits into 'dying search portals' and 'booming data infrastructure' -- another internal bifurcation.

year_by_year_projection.2026: AI search captures 15-20% of information queries (up from 8%). Google AI Overviews generates 3% of search ad revenue. Publisher traffic from search falls another 25-30%. Data infrastructure companies (Snowflake, Databricks, etc.) grow 25%+.
year_by_year_projection.2027: Traditional search advertising peaks and begins secular decline. AI-native search (Perplexity, ChatGPT Search) reaches 25% of query volume. Google restructures search division. Data marketplace for AI training data becomes $10B+ market.
year_by_year_projection.2028: SEO industry collapses (-40% revenue). Content farms that existed for search traffic become unviable. Data labeling and synthetic data generation becomes larger market than traditional web search advertising.
year_by_year_projection.2029: Web portal employment -30% from 2025 baseline. Data services employment +40% from 2025. Net sub-sector employment roughly flat but completely different workforce composition.
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: AI-native information retrieval is default. 'Web search' is legacy terminology. Data infrastructure is the actual growth engine. Sub-sector average pay exceeds $300K as low-skill roles eliminated and data science/AI roles dominate.

current_state.market_dynamics: The most consequential sub-sector in the entire analysis. Software publishing employs 648K at $200K average pay -- the cognitive elite of the economy. AI code generation has reached 82% developer adoption, with 50% using AI tools daily. But the Solow Paradox signal is strong: experienced devs are 19% SLOWER on complex tasks with AI assistance. The market is bifurcating between 'AI makes simple code free' and 'complex system architecture requires more human judgment than ever.'
current_state.employment_trajectory: Still growing at +2.57% but this MASKS internal restructuring. Entry-level developer hiring collapsed 67%. Senior/staff roles growing. The middle is being hollowed: junior developer -> AI pair programmer -> senior architect is the new career ladder, with the junior rung removed. AI code assistant market at $7.4B growing to $24B by 2030 (26.6% CAGR).
key_data_points: 82% of developers use AI tools to write code; 50% daily
85% of software workforce projected to adopt GenAI by 2026
25-40% of Google code is AI-generated
BUT experienced devs 19% SLOWER on complex tasks with AI -- Solow Paradox
Entry-level developer hiring -67% (P-037 Entry-Level Extinction)
AI code assistant market: $7.4B (2025) -> $24B (2030) at 26.6% CAGR
Enterprise AI market: $37B (fastest-scaling category in software history)
Code agents and AI app builders 'exploding from near-zero' (Menlo Ventures)
Software publishers still growing employment +2.57% but quality mix shifting dramatically
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Early-to-mid creative destruction. Software publishers are BOTH the disruptors (selling AI tools) AND the disrupted (their own products being commoditized by AI). Microsoft sells Copilot while Copilot makes competing with Microsoft easier. This is the most extreme Schumpeterian self-referential loop in economic history. The Christensen test: can incumbents adopt AI without cannibalizing revenue? For SaaS companies, the answer is MAYBE -- AI features increase stickiness but also reduce the NEED for the product (if AI can write the code, why buy the software?).
current_state.baumol_dynamics: Baumol score 2.76 with $200K average pay = enormous stored energy. Software development has been a Baumol-exempt sector for 30 years because productivity kept pace with wages. AI code generation is the first technology that threatens to break the Baumol exemption -- if AI writes 60-80% of routine code, the effective cost of a software developer drops, but wages remain sticky. This creates classic Baumol Cure conditions: the price of software SHOULD drop dramatically, but wage stickiness and complexity premiums will create a Baumol Premium for system architects.
current_state.transformation_summary: Software publishing faces the most complex transformation of any sub-sector. The routine-cognitive component (writing boilerplate code, bug fixes, documentation, testing) is being rapidly automated. But the tacit-cognitive component (system architecture, security design, user experience strategy, product vision) is becoming MORE valuable as AI handles the mechanical work. The sector will employ FEWER people at HIGHER average wages, with the eliminated jobs concentrated at entry/junior level. By 2031, 'software publisher' may be a misnomer -- 'AI system orchestrator' better describes the surviving firms.

year_by_year_projection.2026: AI coding adoption reaches 85% of workforce. Code agents handle autonomous module creation (beyond suggestion-based completion). Junior hiring continues to collapse. SaaS companies add AI features to prevent churn, temporarily boosting margins. First wave of 'vibe-coded' applications enter market.
year_by_year_projection.2027: AI-generated code quality reaches senior developer level for 60% of standard tasks. SaaS pricing pressure as 'build vs. buy' equation shifts toward build (with AI assistance). Mid-tier software companies face margin compression. First major SaaS company acquired because AI made its product replicable.
year_by_year_projection.2028: Software publisher employment peaks and begins declining. Architecture/design roles command 2-3x premiums over coding roles. AI code review and security audit become larger markets than code generation. Open-source AI threatens proprietary software moats.
year_by_year_projection.2029: Routine software development employment -20% from 2025. System architecture employment +15%. Net sector employment -10%. Average pay rises to $220K+ as low-paid roles eliminated. The 'software is eating the world' era transitions to 'AI is eating software.'
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: Software publishing restructured: firms are AI system orchestrators, not code writers. Employment -25% from 2025 but revenue +30% (AI efficiency). The surviving workforce is 80% senior/architect level. Entry-level pipeline crisis (P-037) creates acute shortage of experienced architects by 2031.

sub_sector_analysis.name: Internet Publishing and Web Search Portals (Digital Content/Media)

current_state.market_dynamics: The most extreme Baumol signature in the entire NAICS 51 sector: employment declining -6.36% while wages surge +16.4%. This sub-sector spans digital media, internet publishing, and online content platforms. It is being squeezed from TWO directions: (1) AI-generated content floods the supply side (Deezer reports 50,000 fully AI-generated songs uploaded DAILY by end 2025, up from 10,000 at start of year), and (2) AI search reduces demand for web-published content (organic search traffic for publishers down 25-50% from AI Overviews and zero-click results).
current_state.employment_trajectory: Accelerating decline. Washington Post laid off 1/3 of staff (Feb 2026). Entertainment and media layoffs up 18% with 17,000+ jobs in 2025. 3,000+ journalism job cuts in UK/US in 2025 alone. The survivors command ever-higher wages ($239K average, +16.4% growth) because the remaining roles are high-judgment editorial/strategy positions. This is textbook Barbell Economy formation: middle eliminated, premium and commodity endpoints remain.
key_data_points: Employment -6.36% with wage growth +16.4% = most extreme Baumol signature in NAICS 51
Washington Post: 1/3 of staff laid off (Feb 2026), organic search traffic down ~50% in 3 years
Entertainment/media layoffs +18% YoY with 17,000+ cuts in 2025
AI-generated content: 50,000 fully AI songs uploaded to Deezer daily (5x growth in 2025)
Europol: 90% of online content may be synthetic by 2026
AI Overviews on Google reducing publisher click-through by 25-40%
SEO industry facing existential threat from AI search transformation
Digital advertising remains strong ($740B+ global 2026) but flows to platforms, not publishers
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Active destruction phase. The internet publishing model (create content -> attract search traffic -> sell ads) is being destroyed by AI on both sides. AI creates competing content at near-zero marginal cost, AND AI search eliminates the traffic that makes ad-supported publishing viable. Schumpeterian destruction is not 'coming' -- it is HERE.
current_state.baumol_dynamics: Baumol Destruction (not Cure). High wages ($239K) would normally suggest Baumol Cure potential, but AI is not just compressing costs -- it is eliminating the REVENUE mechanism. When AI can write articles, create images, compose music, and answer queries directly, the economic basis for internet publishing as an employer collapses. The surviving premium is 'verified human' content creation and editorial judgment that AI cannot replicate.
current_state.transformation_summary: Internet publishing is undergoing the most violent transformation in NAICS 51. Content creation at commodity level is becoming effectively free (AI-generated). The premium shifts to: (1) original investigative journalism, (2) verified human authenticity, (3) editorial curation/judgment, (4) live/experiential content that AI cannot generate. Employment will continue declining 5-10% annually through 2031, with survivors commanding $300K+ as the work becomes pure judgment/trust/brand.

year_by_year_projection.2026: Publisher layoffs continue. AI search captures 15-20% of queries. Content authentication/verification becomes emerging market. First major publisher pivots to 'AI-free' brand positioning. Synthetic content detection tools reach $1B market.
year_by_year_projection.2027: 30% of mid-tier digital publishers cease operations or merge. Surviving publishers split into two models: premium (NYT, Bloomberg -- subscription + verified human) and AI-augmented (AI-generated with human editorial layer). Advertising revenue shifts further to platform-native AI.
year_by_year_projection.2028: Internet publishing employment -30% from 2025. 'Content authentication' becomes standard (like SSL certificates). Verified human content commands 3-5x premium over AI content. Journalism restructures around investigation + verification, not information delivery.
year_by_year_projection.2029: Consolidation wave: 3-5 major digital media conglomerates survive at scale. Niche/specialist publishers thrive on subscriber loyalty. General interest publishing largely AI-automated. Employment stabilizes at -40% from 2025 peak.
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: Surviving internet publishers are either premium subscription models or AI-native content factories. Employment at roughly 130K-140K (from 226K), but average pay exceeds $300K. The sector has barbelled: AI-generated commodity content (near-zero cost) and human-verified premium content (5-10x historical cost).

sub_sector_analysis.name: Motion Picture and Sound Recording Industries

current_state.market_dynamics: The most dramatic employment collapse in NAICS 51 at -13.91% (v3-6 signals suggest -24.1% including contract/gig workers). Uniquely among information sub-sectors, motion picture has LOW average pay ($85K) and LOW Baumol score (1.17) -- this is NOT a Baumol Cure target but rather a DEMAND COLLAPSE. Post-pandemic streaming bubble bursting, Hollywood production down, and AI threatening VFX, animation, and post-production workflows.
current_state.employment_trajectory: Catastrophic. One-third of US game industry workers laid off in 2025. Hollywood analysts project 100,000-200,000 entertainment jobs disrupted by AI by end of 2026. Union contracts expire in 2026, raising fears of another labor stoppage. VFX artists, animators, 3D modelers most immediately vulnerable.
key_data_points: Employment -13.91% (QCEW) to -24.1% (v3-6 signals including gig workers)
Average pay $85K -- lowest in NAICS 51, below economy-wide average for this skill level
1/3 of US game developers laid off in 2025
100,000-200,000 entertainment jobs projected disrupted by AI by end 2026
52% of game industry professionals say GenAI having negative impact (up from 18% two years ago)
Studios spending <3% of production budgets on AI tools (cautious adoption) but 7% on operational AI
AI music: 50,000 fully AI songs uploaded to Deezer daily. Suno/Udio settled with major labels
Union contracts expire 2026 -- potential labor action
LA production volume declining (Hollywood review 2025)
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Accelerated destruction. Unlike software publishing where the sector is partially self-disrupting, motion picture is being disrupted by EXTERNAL AI tools (Sora, Runway, Suno, Udio) that originate in the tech sector. The industry's union structure and guild system creates higher institutional resistance but also higher cliff-risk -- when adoption breaks through, it will be sudden, not gradual.
current_state.baumol_dynamics: LOW Baumol score (1.17) indicates this is NOT a Baumol Cure sector. Wages are low and have not outpaced productivity for decades (film industry already compressed wages through gig/contract structure). AI impact here is DEMAND destruction and SUBSTITUTION, not cost-disease cure. The few Baumol Premium roles (A-list directors, star actors, showrunners) will command even higher premiums as AI handles everything below them.
current_state.transformation_summary: Motion picture is the canary in the NAICS 51 coal mine. Low wages, high gig dependency, and creative work that AI can increasingly approximate make this the most vulnerable sub-sector. But creative originality, star talent, and live performance remain Baumol Premium. The sector restructures around a much smaller core of premium human creatives directing AI production tools, with middle-tier production roles (VFX, animation, editing, sound design) largely automated.

year_by_year_projection.2026: Union contract negotiations dominate. Studios cautiously adopt AI for dubbing, localization, previz. First 'significantly AI-aided' film released (per industry analysts). Game industry continues restructuring. AI music settles into licensed model (Suno/Udio deals).
year_by_year_projection.2027: Post-contract landscape: AI usage terms defined. Production costs drop 15-25% for mid-budget content. AI-generated short-form content floods streaming platforms. Premium theatrical releases double down on human-craft quality as differentiator.
year_by_year_projection.2028: Employment -35% from 2025 baseline. AI handles 60%+ of VFX, animation, and post-production for mid-tier content. Premium content (tentpole films, prestige TV) maintains human-heavy production. Independent film renaissance as AI lowers production costs to near-zero.
year_by_year_projection.2029: Industry stabilizes around bimodal structure: premium human-craft content (expensive, scarce, high-value) and AI-augmented mass content (cheap, abundant, lower-value). Middle-budget production nearly eliminated.
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: Employment at 220K-250K (from 378K). Average pay rises to $100K+ as low-paid gig roles eliminated and premium creative roles command higher compensation. 'Content' is no longer scarce -- curation, quality verification, and live experience are the scarce resources.

current_state.market_dynamics: The LARGEST sub-sector by employment (935K) combining traditional publishing and telecommunications. Employment nearly flat (-0.26%) but this masks divergent dynamics: telecom employment declining 1-2% annually as network automation advances, while publishing employment declining 3-5% annually from AI content generation and search traffic loss. Telecom is pivoting to AI-as-infrastructure, positioning physical networks as 'AI grids' for distributed inference.
current_state.employment_trajectory: Gradual decline overall. Telecom undergoing transformation from connectivity provider to AI infrastructure provider. Traditional publishing (newspapers, books, periodicals) in accelerating decline: media industry lost 14,298 jobs/year since 2018 (2x the 2010-2017 rate). But telecom AI investment creating new roles in network AI, edge computing, and private 5G.
key_data_points: 935K employees -- largest NAICS 51 sub-sector by headcount
Telecom AI transformation: 84% of telco executives agree AI agents will reinvent operations
Private 5G enterprise network market: $5.7B in 2026, projected $29.7B by 2030
AI in telecom market: $8.76B (2025), projected $203B by 2035
Traditional publishing: media lost 14,298 jobs/year since 2018 (accelerating from 7,305 pre-2018)
Washington Post layoffs (1/3 of staff) signal institutional media collapse
Telecom service commoditization: global revenue stagnation despite 5G rollout
Telcos repositioning as 'distributed AI grids' for token processing at scale
current_state.schumpeterian_position: Pre-disruption to early disruption. Telecom infrastructure has long replacement cycles (10-20 year network lifecycles) that slow Schumpeterian dynamics. But AI-native network architectures are the first technology that could compress this cycle. Publishing within 513 is further along the destruction curve. The combined sub-sector masks the divergence.
current_state.baumol_dynamics: Moderate Baumol score (2.35) driven by telecom wages outpacing productivity gains in network operations. AI network automation (predictive maintenance, autonomous operations) represents a genuine Baumol Cure for telecom operations. Publishing Baumol dynamics are similar to 5162 -- Baumol Destruction rather than Cure.
current_state.transformation_summary: 513 is two stories in one NAICS code. Telecom transforms from connectivity commodity to AI infrastructure provider -- the physical network becomes the 'last mile' for AI inference. Publishing transforms (or collapses) as AI content generation and AI search eliminate the traditional model. Both trajectories point to fewer workers, higher skills, and AI-augmented operations.

year_by_year_projection.2026: Telecom begins AI-native network deployments (agentic AI for operations, predictive maintenance). Private 5G reaches 6,500+ deployments. Publishing layoffs continue at accelerated pace.
year_by_year_projection.2027: First telcos offer 'AI grid' services (distributed inference on network edge). 6G research funding increases. Traditional publishing employment -10% from 2025.
year_by_year_projection.2028: Telecom employment stabilizes as AI operations roles offset traditional operations cuts. Publishing employment -20% from 2025. Local newspapers near extinction except as AI-augmented community platforms.
year_by_year_projection.2029: AI-native 6G trials begin. Telecom revenue per employee rises 20%+ from AI optimization. Publishing survivors are subscription-premium or AI-augmented.
year_by_year_projection.2030-2031: Total 513 employment at 800K-850K (from 935K). Telecom portion stable-to-growing as AI grid services create new revenue. Publishing portion contracted by 30-40%.

2026_current_state.headline: The Great Bifurcation Accelerates
dynamics: Infrastructure (518): $700B+ hyperscaler capex, data center capacity crisis (95%+ occupancy), power constraints as binding limit
Software (5132): AI coding at 82% adoption, entry-level hiring -67%, Solow Paradox (experienced devs 19% slower with AI)
Content (512, 5162): Motion picture -14% to -24% employment, WashPo layoff 1/3, AI search captures 8-15% of queries
Data (519): Baumol 3.72 -- highest score, $270K avg pay, search portals dying while data infrastructure booms
Telecom/Publishing (513): Stable overall but masking telecom-AI pivot vs publishing collapse
Capital concentration: Top 5 tech companies spending $700B combined on AI infrastructure
2026_current_state.key_threshold: AI search market share crosses 15% of queries -- triggers accelerating publisher traffic loss

dynamics: Software publisher employment peaks and begins declining
Architecture/design roles command 2-3x premiums over coding roles

Data center REITs split into AI-optimized vs legacy tiers (3-5x valuation gap)
