2028_second_order_cascade.key_threshold: Software developer employment growth turns negative for the first time

2029_structural_reconfiguration.headline: New Equilibrium Emerges
dynamics: Routine software development employment -20% from 2025; system architecture +15%
Media industry bimodal: premium human-craft vs AI-augmented mass content
Data infrastructure exceeds web search advertising as revenue category
AI inference at edge becomes standard
Industry consolidation across all sub-sectors
Net NAICS 51 employment approximately -15% from 2025
2029_structural_reconfiguration.key_threshold: AI-generated content exceeds human-generated content by volume across all categories

2030_2031_new_economy.headline: The Information Sector Restructured
dynamics: NAICS 51 employment at ~2.3-2.5M (from 2.98M in 2025): -16% to -23%
Average pay rises from $155K to $185K-$200K (low-paid roles eliminated)
Revenue grows +30-50% despite employment decline (AI productivity)
Infrastructure (518) is the dominant sub-sector by revenue and strategic importance
Software publishing (5132) has barbelled: AI system orchestrators at premium + commodity AI-app builders
Content creation (512, 5162) has restructured around premium human + AI production tools
The P-037 Entry-Level Extinction crisis manifests: acute shortage of experienced architects/engineers with 5-7 years experience
Data center electricity at 6-12% of US grid
2030_2031_new_economy.key_threshold: Entry-level engineering pipeline crisis creates wage spikes for mid-career talent

second_order_effects.description: As AI code generation commoditizes software, IT consulting and systems integration (NAICS 5415, 2.46M workers) faces fundamental disruption. If clients can build with AI, they need fewer consultants. Accenture, Deloitte, Infosys IT practices face 20-30% headcount reduction by 2030.
second_order_effects.evidence: AI coding at 82% adoption. India IT services face $100K H-1B fee + AI substitution dual squeeze. Entry-level developer hiring -67% already affecting staffing pipeline.

second_order_effects.description: Entry-level developer hiring -67% destroys the economic return on computer science degrees. CS enrollment already peaked in 2020. By 2028, CS programs face declining enrollment as the career path becomes less certain. This cascades to university funding (CS departments are cash cows subsidizing other departments), student loan demand, and college town economies.
second_order_effects.evidence: P-037 Entry-Level Extinction confirmed. 67% junior dev hiring collapse. 37% managers prefer AI over Gen Z hire. CS enrollment peaked 2020. College enrollment cliff already hitting.

second_order_effects.description: Information sector employment decline compounds the existing office CMBS crisis (12.34% delinquency, all-time record). Tech companies are the largest premium office tenants in SF, NYC, Seattle, Austin. Employment decline + remote work = tech office vacancy rises from 20% to 30%+ in tech hub cities. This accelerates the CRE cascade (P-026).
second_order_effects.evidence: Office CMBS delinquency 12.34% (above 2008). Tech companies are largest premium tenants. SF office vacancy already 30%+. Information sector employment -2.33% and declining.

second_order_effects.description: AI search reducing publisher traffic -> ad revenue flows from publishers to platforms -> AI-generated content floods supply side -> ad pricing pressure. The $740B global digital advertising market restructures: programmatic advertising on traditional web declines; AI-native ad formats (sponsored AI answers, AI-generated ad creative) grow. This cascades to advertising agencies (NAICS 5418), media buying firms, and marketing technology companies.
second_order_effects.evidence: AI search capturing 8-15% of queries. AI Overviews reducing publisher click-through 25-40%. Gartner: 25% search volume decline by 2026. Google AI Overviews ads growing from 1% to 6-7% by 2027.

second_order_effects.description: Data center electricity demand doubling to 945 TWh by 2030 (IEA) cascades to: utility capacity planning, nuclear renaissance (10GW+ committed), grid modernization investment, and power market pricing. PJM capacity auction at $16.4B (3rd record) with data centers driving 63% of the increase. This creates a physical constraint on NAICS 51 growth itself -- a Jevons Paradox where cheaper AI compute drives more demand than the grid can supply.
second_order_effects.evidence: P-038 AI Infrastructure Chain Constraint confirmed. IEA 945 TWh by 2030. PJM $16.4B auction. 2,600 GW in queue, 5+ year wait. Data center occupancy 95%+ by late 2026.

second_order_effects.description: AI content generation transforms the broader creative economy beyond NAICS 51. When AI can generate music, images, video, text, and code, every sector that BUYS creative work is affected. Marketing budgets shift from agency fees to AI tools. Corporate communications become AI-generated. Training content production costs drop 80%. This is a $500B+ reallocation across the economy.
second_order_effects.evidence: AI-generated content reaching critical scale (50K AI songs/day on Deezer alone). Studios adopting AI for 7% of operational spend. Enterprise GenAI $37B market. Content creation costs approaching near-zero marginal cost for commodity content.

second_order_effects.effect_name: AI Safety and Governance Market Creation
second_order_effects.description: The information sector's self-disruption creates DEMAND for governance, safety, compliance, and authentication services. If 90% of online content becomes synthetic (Europol projection), content authentication, AI safety auditing, and trust verification become essential infrastructure. This is a new market created entirely by NAICS 51's transformation.
second_order_effects.evidence: Fear economy TAM ~$86B by 2030 (governance $15.8B + safety $9.8B + cybersecurity $60.6B). Europol 90% synthetic content projection. Deepfake 16x growth (500K to 8M 2023-2025). Content authentication emerging market. AI Governance and Compliance OS is top-scoring model (84.0).

routine_cognitive_tasks: Content creation at commodity level (articles, summaries, reports)
Data entry and basic data processing
Standard video editing, color correction, sound mixing (motion picture)
Basic journalism (event coverage, earnings reports, press release rewrites)
tacit_manual_tasks: Data center physical operations (racking, cabling, cooling maintenance)
On-location film production (camera, lighting, set construction)
Hardware installation and repair (telecom field technicians)
Studio recording (live music, foley, practical effects)
tacit_cognitive_tasks: Product strategy and user experience vision
AI system design and prompt engineering at scale
Network architecture for novel requirements (AI grids, edge computing)
Algorithm design and optimization for novel problems
sector_level_analysis.net_effect: The information sector barbells more dramatically than any other sector because the routine-cognitive component (50%) is EXACTLY what AI does best -- information processing, content generation, code writing. The tacit-cognitive component (45%) commands growing premiums because judgment, creativity, and strategic vision become more valuable as execution becomes free. The tacit-manual component (5%) is small but durable -- you cannot AI your way out of physically racking servers or filming on location.

premium_tier.description: Roles that become MORE valuable as AI handles routine work

roles.rationale: Designing AI systems that orchestrate other AI systems requires judgment that AI cannot self-generate. The architect decides WHAT to build and WHY, not HOW (which AI handles).
As AI writes more code and generates more content, the attack surface expands exponentially. Security judgment is tacit-cognitive and becomes more critical as AI-generated systems proliferate.
AI makes execution cheap. Vision and taste become the scarce inputs. A creative director who can orchestrate AI production tools to execute their vision has 10x the output of today.
AI cannot cultivate human sources, conduct undercover investigations, or exercise editorial judgment about public interest. These become premium as commodity journalism is AI-generated.
AI creates insatiable demand for data. Designing the data pipelines, governance frameworks, and infrastructure that feed AI systems is tacit-cognitive work with growing demand.

commodity_tier.description: Roles that become AI-substitutable, with wages converging toward AI-tool-operator compensation

roles.projected_2031_status: Reduced 60-70%. Remaining roles are 'AI pair programming operators' at $60K-$90K.
roles.rationale: AI code generation handles 80%+ of routine coding tasks. Junior devs who survive will primarily review and test AI output.

roles.projected_2031_status: Reduced 70-80%. Remaining roles are 'AI content editors' at $40K-$70K.
roles.rationale: AI-generated content quality exceeds average human output for informational/commercial content. Human editors review AI output rather than creating from scratch.

roles.projected_2031_status: Reduced 50-60%. Remaining roles shift to 'AI VFX director' overseeing AI-generated output.
roles.rationale: AI handles 60%+ of standard VFX/animation work by 2028. Premium creative VFX survives; routine production VFX is automated.

roles.projected_2031_status: Category near-eliminated. Transforms into 'AI visibility optimizer' at reduced comp.
roles.rationale: Traditional SEO becomes irrelevant as AI search replaces web search. New role focuses on visibility within AI answer engines, fundamentally different skill set.

roles.projected_2031_status: Reduced 40-50%. AI handles routine monitoring; humans handle exceptions only.
roles.rationale: Agentic AI for network operations automates 70-80% of NOC functions by 2029.

518_computing_infrastructure.notes: Physical infrastructure creates more durable employment than pure-digital sub-sectors

519_web_search_data.notes: Extreme bifurcation -- data infrastructure premium vs search portal elimination

5132_software_publishers.notes: Largest absolute job elimination in NAICS 51; architecture premium highest

5162_internet_publishing.notes: Most severe elimination rate -- AI-generated content destroys the employment model

512_motion_picture.notes: Creative premium survives but production middle eliminated

513_publishing_telecom.notes: Telecom infrastructure jobs more durable than publishing jobs

model_cards.one_line: AI platform automating data center operations (cooling, power, workload scheduling) to achieve 15-25% efficiency gains at 95%+ occupancy rates
model_cards.macro_source: P-038 AI Infrastructure Chain Constraint + F6 energy constraints + 518 employment +4.08%

structural_necessity.justification: Data center occupancy at 95%+ by late 2026 means operators MUST optimize existing capacity. $1T+ annual capex creates demand for efficiency tools. Power grid constraints (2,600 GW queue, 5+ year wait) make optimization more critical than expansion. Every percentage point of efficiency gain = billions in avoided capex.

force_alignment.justification: Aligned with F1 (AI for operations), F6 (energy efficiency critical), and F4 (massive capital flowing to infrastructure). P-038 AI Infrastructure Chain Constraint means each optimization layer creates compound value. Microsoft's zero-water cooling pilot shows hyperscalers actively pursuing AI-driven efficiency.

external_context.justification: Global market -- US, EU, India, Gulf all building data centers. EU AI Act delays reduce regulatory friction. India zero-tax-through-2047 creates new market. But hyperscalers may build internally rather than buy (competitive risk from AWS, Azure, Google engineering teams).

timing_grade.justification: Optimal window 2026-2028 as capacity crisis forces adoption. Revenue-generating within 6 months (efficiency gains measurable immediately). Perez turning point resilient -- data center optimization needed in both boom and bust. Physical infrastructure = crash resistant.

capital_efficiency.justification: Software + sensors platform. $2-5M to MVP. 75-80% gross margins. Data flywheel (more deployments = better optimization models). But requires domain expertise in power systems, cooling, and workload scheduling that narrows talent pool.

model_cards.category_justification: SN >= 9.0 not met (8.5) but composite 82.0 with SN 8.5 + FA 9.0 qualifies as borderline. Reclassify as FORCE_RIDER given SN < 9.0 per hard enforcement rules.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $50K-$200K/month per data center facility (based on size and optimization scope)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x -- efficiency gains allow more workloads per facility, expanding compute availability

moat_sources: Hardware sensor integration creates switching costs

falsification_criteria: If hyperscalers build all optimization internally (reduces TAM to mid-market/colocation only)
If power grid constraints ease faster than projected (reduces urgency)
If data center demand growth slows due to AI training efficiency gains (reduces occupancy pressure)
If competing platform achieves dominant market share before 2027 (first-mover advantage lost)

model_cards.model_name: AI Code Quality and Security Audit Platform
model_cards.one_line: Platform providing automated security auditing, code review, and quality assurance for AI-generated code, addressing the 'trust gap' as 82% of developers use AI coding tools
model_cards.macro_source: P-036 Anticipatory Displacement + 5132 Baumol 2.76 + AI coding 82% adoption

structural_necessity.justification: 82% of developers using AI coding tools means billions of lines of AI-generated code entering production systems. AI-generated code has different vulnerability patterns than human code. Security auditing of AI output is structurally necessary -- no organization can ship AI-generated code without verification. This is the 'AI writes the code, humans verify it' business model for the entire software industry.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (AI creates the problem AND the solution -- AI auditing AI code), F5 (enterprise fear of AI-generated vulnerabilities drives adoption), F4 (cybersecurity spending at $60.6B growing to $86B). Aligned with P-036 (anticipatory displacement creates demand for verification) and P-038 (security is part of AI infrastructure chain).

external_context.justification: Global need -- every geography writing AI-generated code needs auditing. EU AI Act (despite delay) will require AI system documentation including code provenance. US state-level AI regulation creating compliance demand. But market is crowded (Snyk, Veracode, SonarQube, plus AI-native entrants).

timing_grade.justification: Window opening NOW as AI code adoption reaches critical mass (82%). Revenue immediate (enterprises already need this). Crash resilient -- security spending is counter-cyclical (rises in downturns as fear increases). First-mover advantage as AI-specific security patterns are novel.

capital_efficiency.justification: $1-3M to MVP. 80%+ gross margins (software-only). Data flywheel: more code analyzed = better vulnerability detection. API-first architecture enables rapid integration with existing CI/CD pipelines. Low customer acquisition cost -- integrates with tools developers already use.

model_cards.category_justification: SN 9.0 meets threshold. Composite 82.5. Security + AI code convergence creates structural necessity that persists regardless of market conditions. Qualifies for STRUCTURAL_WINNER.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $500-$5,000/month per development team (tiered by repo count and scan frequency)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $50-$500/team/month (AI inference for code scanning + pattern database)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $2,000-$10,000/month for manual code review + separate security audit tools
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3x -- as AI-generated code volume grows 5-10x, security scanning demand grows proportionally

moat_sources: AI-generated code specific vulnerability database (novel patterns)
Integration with AI coding tools (Copilot, Cursor, Claude Code)
Real-time scanning during AI code generation (not post-hoc)

falsification_criteria: If AI coding tools build in sufficient security themselves (Copilot adding security scanning natively)
If AI-generated code proves no more vulnerable than human code (reduces urgency)
If major enterprise breach traced to AI-generated code triggers over-regulation that blocks AI coding adoption
If existing security vendors (Snyk, Veracode) successfully extend to AI-specific patterns

model_cards.one_line: Infrastructure platform providing cryptographic content authentication and provenance verification as AI-generated content approaches 90% of online content (Europol projection)
model_cards.macro_source: P-036 Anticipatory Displacement + F5 deepfake trust collapse + 519 Baumol 3.72

structural_necessity.justification: Europol projects 90% of online content may be synthetic by 2026. 8M deepfakes in 2025 (16x from 2023). 'Liar's Dividend' threatens democratic discourse. Content authentication becomes infrastructure-level necessity (like SSL/TLS for security). C2PA and similar standards creating foundation but no dominant platform.

force_alignment.justification: F5 (trust collapse is the primary driver -- deepfake fear creates demand), F1 (AI creates the problem; cryptographic verification and AI detection create the solution), F3 (state-level regulation in 2026 mandating AI content labeling creates compliance requirement). Fear economy TAM $86B by 2030.

external_context.justification: Global need -- every country faces synthetic content challenge. EU AI Act requires AI content labeling (despite enforcement delay). US state bills targeting AI content disclosure. India, UK, Japan all developing content authentication standards. First-mover in standard-setting has outsized advantage (like Verisign for SSL).

timing_grade.justification: Market forming now but monetization uncertain. Standards (C2PA) still evolving. Revenue path: enterprise licensing (media companies, platforms) + API calls for verification. Moderate crash resilience -- trust infrastructure is necessary but adoption depends on ecosystem coordination.

capital_efficiency.justification: $5-10M to build platform + achieve standard compliance. Network effects are critical (value increases with adoption). Platform economics but high initial investment and ecosystem coordination costs. Margins improve dramatically at scale (80%+ for verification API).

model_cards.category_justification: F5 psychology is the PRIMARY force driver. Content authentication is directly created by fear of synthetic content. Fear economy criteria met: demand would not exist without AI fear. FEAR_ECONOMY category per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $10K-$100K/month per enterprise customer (media companies, platforms) + $0.001-$0.01 per API verification call
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: No direct incumbent -- this is a NEW market category
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 50-100 enterprise customers OR 100M+ monthly API calls
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 5x+ -- as synthetic content volume grows exponentially, verification demand grows proportionally

moat_sources: Network effects (more verified content = more valuable platform)
Integration with major content platforms and browsers

falsification_criteria: If AI detection technology fails to keep pace with AI generation (arms race lost)
If major platforms build authentication internally (Google, Meta have resources)
If public apathy toward synthetic content means no market demand ('people don't care')
If regulatory requirements for content labeling are weakened or unenforced

model_cards.one_line: Premium digital media platform combining AI research/analysis tools with human investigative journalists, targeting the 'verified human' premium as AI-generated content floods commodity news
model_cards.macro_source: P-001 Baumol Cure + 5162 Baumol 3.30 + F5 trust collapse

structural_necessity.justification: As AI-generated content reaches 90% of online content, 'verified human' journalism becomes a premium good. The structural necessity is driven by trust collapse -- democratic societies NEED credible information sources. But necessity is mediated by willingness to pay (subscription model dependency). NYT, Bloomberg prove premium subscription model works; question is how many can sustain it.

force_alignment.justification: F5 (trust collapse drives premium for verified human content), F1 (AI tools make human journalists 3-5x more productive at research/analysis), F4 (PE distress in media creates acquisition opportunities for premium brands). Counter-force: AI-generated news commoditizes the base layer.

external_context.justification: US-centric opportunity (subscription models work in English-language markets). EU regulatory environment supportive (press subsidies, AI content labeling). But audience size for premium journalism is limited -- perhaps 10-20M households willing to pay $200+/yr per publication.

timing_grade.justification: Window opening now as publisher layoffs (WashPo 1/3 staff) create talent availability and brand distress. Crash resilient -- information demand is counter-cyclical. But building subscriber base takes 2-3 years minimum.

capital_efficiency.justification: High-talent model (investigative journalists are expensive, $100K-$300K each). Revenue per subscriber lower than SaaS ($200-$500/yr vs $1K-$10K/yr). Margins improve with AI augmentation (AI handles research, journalists handle judgment). But capital-intensive talent acquisition.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite below 70.0. Model is viable but conditional on subscriber growth and trust premium monetization. CONDITIONAL per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $200-$500/year per subscriber. $50K-$200K/year per institutional subscriber (hedge funds, law firms, corporate intelligence).
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $5-$20/subscriber/year (AI research tools, content generation assistance, analytics)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 50K-100K paid subscribers (at $300/yr average) to support 50-person investigative team
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x -- premium journalism has limited demand expansion (people pay for trust, which has inherent scarcity)

falsification_criteria: If AI-generated journalism quality exceeds human investigative quality (removes trust premium)
If 'verified human' branding fails to command price premium (consumer indifference)
If subscriber acquisition costs exceed $200/subscriber (unit economics fail)
If media consolidation blocks independent publishers from distribution

model_cards.model_name: Telecom AI Operations Platform (AIOps for Network Infrastructure)
model_cards.one_line: AI platform for autonomous telecom network operations -- predictive maintenance, traffic optimization, and agentic AI for NOC automation, targeting $203B AI-in-telecom market by 2035
model_cards.macro_source: 513 Baumol 2.35 + Telecom AI transformation + F1 agentic AI + F6 energy grid nexus

structural_necessity.justification: 84% of telco executives agree AI agents will reinvent operations. Telecom service commoditization means margins compress unless costs compress faster -- AI operations is the structural answer. Network complexity increasing (5G, private networks, AI grids) while workforce declining. AI-native network architectures are inevitable.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (agentic AI for network operations is frontier capability -- multi-agent systems for complex network management), F6 (telecom infrastructure critical for AI data center connectivity), F4 (AI in telecom market $8.76B growing to $203B by 2035). Private 5G market $5.7B in 2026.

external_context.justification: Global opportunity -- every telecom operator globally faces same cost/complexity squeeze. EU and Asian markets adopt faster than US for telecom AI. India's data center buildout creates telecom infrastructure demand. But incumbent telecom vendors (Ericsson, Nokia, Huawei) have deep relationships.

timing_grade.justification: 2026 is 'pivot year' for telecom AI (per Omdia). But telecom sales cycles are 12-24 months (long). Revenue timing: 6-12 months from first POC to deployment. Crash resilient -- telecom infrastructure spend is essential-services level.

capital_efficiency.justification: $3-8M to MVP (requires network domain expertise + AI). 70-75% gross margins for SaaS. Long sales cycles reduce capital efficiency. But high LTV (telecom customers have 5-10 year contracts). Data flywheel from network telemetry.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 76.0 with strong F1 alignment. FA 8.0 qualifies for FORCE_RIDER. Not structural winner (SN 8.0 < 9.0).

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $100K-$500K/year per telecom operator (based on network size and automation scope)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $500K-$2M/year per operator (manual NOC staffing + legacy management tools)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x -- lower operations costs enable telecom operators to deploy more network capacity, especially for AI data center connectivity

falsification_criteria: If incumbent telecom vendors (Ericsson, Nokia) build superior AI operations tools
If telecom operators build internally rather than buy
If telecom industry consolidation reduces number of potential customers
If AI grid concept fails (telcos don't successfully pivot to AI infrastructure)

model_cards.model_name: AI-Native SaaS Rebuilder / Software M&A Platform
model_cards.one_line: Acquire mid-market SaaS companies facing margin pressure from AI commoditization, rebuild products with AI-native architecture at 60-80% lower development cost, and operate as AI-efficient portfolio
model_cards.macro_source: P-001 Baumol Cure + 5132 Baumol 2.76 + F4 PE refinancing wall + Schumpeterian gap in software

structural_necessity.justification: PE-backed SaaS companies facing double squeeze: $930B PE debt maturing 2026 + AI commoditization of their products. Distress rate 11.98% (+148%). Many mid-market SaaS products can be rebuilt with AI at 60-80% lower cost. Acquisition window open as PE funds need exits. Silver Tsunami (52.3% of businesses owned by 55+) creates additional acquisition supply.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (AI code generation enables 60-80% cheaper product development), F4 (PE refinancing wall creates forced sellers at 2-4x EBITDA), F2 (founder aging creates willingness to sell). Triple alignment creates a Schumpeterian acquisition window: buy distressed SaaS, rebuild with AI, operate at structurally lower cost.

external_context.justification: US-centric (PE refinancing wall is primarily US phenomenon). EU SaaS market has different dynamics. Requires significant capital access and operational expertise. Competition from larger PE firms executing similar strategy.

timing_grade.justification: Optimal window 2026-2028 during PE refinancing wall peak. By 2029, distressed assets are either acquired or restructured. First-mover advantage in sector-specific SaaS (vertical market SaaS most vulnerable). Revenue from Day 1 (acquired companies have existing revenue). Crash BENEFICIAL -- recession accelerates distress, creating more acquisition targets.

capital_efficiency.justification: $5-20M per acquisition. SBA 7a/504 loans available for smaller deals. Revenue-generating from Day 1. AI rebuild reduces headcount 40-60% within 12 months (margin expansion). But capital-intensive roll-up strategy has execution risk.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 77.5. Strong FA 8.5 and TG 8.5 but SN 8.0 prevents STRUCTURAL_WINNER. F4 capital force is primary driver. FORCE_RIDER per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: Acquired revenue: $1M-$10M ARR per SaaS company
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: AI rebuild: $200K-$1M per product (vs $2-5M original development cost). Operating team: 3-5 AI-augmented engineers per product (vs 10-20 pre-acquisition).
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: Original development cost $2-5M. Operating team 10-20 engineers at $200K avg = $2-4M/yr overhead.
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 2-3 acquisitions to create operational portfolio. Payback period: 18-30 months per acquisition.
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x -- lower SaaS prices from AI-rebuilt products expand market (currently unserved SMBs access enterprise-grade tools)

falsification_criteria: If AI-generated software quality insufficient to replace mid-market SaaS products
If PE firms execute AI-rebuild strategy themselves (using internal portfolio operations teams)
If customer churn during product transition exceeds 30% (destroying acquired value)
If AI code generation does not reliably reduce development costs by 60%+ (Solow Paradox persists)

model_cards.model_name: AI Training Data Marketplace and Licensing Platform
model_cards.one_line: Marketplace connecting data owners (publishers, enterprises, creators) with AI companies needing licensed training data, with automated rights management and compliance
model_cards.macro_source: 519 Baumol 3.72 + AI training data demand explosion + copyright settlement wave (Suno/Udio)

structural_necessity.justification: AI model training requires data. Copyright lawsuits (NYT v. OpenAI, Suno/Udio music settlements) are forcing AI companies to LICENSE data rather than scrape. The Suno/Udio settlements with major labels prove the model: AI companies WILL pay for licensed, rights-cleared training data. This creates a structural need for a marketplace that connects data suppliers with AI model trainers.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (AI model training creates insatiable data demand), F3 (EU AI Act requires training data documentation; US copyright enforcement accelerating), F4 ($37B enterprise GenAI market needs compliant data supply). But data marketplace dynamics are winner-take-most (network effects favor consolidation).

external_context.justification: Global -- EU AI Act Article 53 requires training data documentation. US copyright enforcement creating compliance need. Suno/Udio settlements prove AI companies will pay for licensed data. Music, publishing, image, and video data all need licensing infrastructure.

timing_grade.justification: Window opening now as copyright enforcement creates urgency. But marketplace building takes time (chicken-and-egg: need both data suppliers and AI buyers). First significant revenue in 12-18 months. Moderate crash resilience -- AI companies may reduce data spending in downturn but licensing compliance is sticky.

capital_efficiency.justification: $3-8M to build marketplace infrastructure + rights management system. Take rate: 15-25% of transaction value (marketplace economics). High margins at scale but requires significant investment in rights management technology and legal compliance. Network effects create eventual moat.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 76.5. F1 technology force is primary driver. SN 8.0 below STRUCTURAL_WINNER threshold. FORCE_RIDER per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: 15-25% take rate on data licensing transactions. Expected $500K-$5M per major AI company customer annually.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: Rights management infrastructure: $100K-$500K/year. AI-powered content classification and compliance: $50K-$200K/year.
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: Manual licensing (rights agencies, publishers): 35-50% take rate with 3-6 month negotiation cycles.
unit_economics.break_even_volume: $20M-$30M in annual gross merchandise value (GMV) through the platform
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3-5x -- accessible, compliant training data enables MORE AI model development, expanding the AI ecosystem

falsification_criteria: If synthetic data generation quality eliminates need for real-world training data
If AI companies successfully defend fair use claims (eliminating licensing necessity)
If major platforms (Google, Microsoft) build proprietary data licensing directly
If data marketplace fails to achieve liquidity (chicken-and-egg problem unsolved)

model_cards.one_line: AI platform for streaming services providing content performance prediction, automated metadata enrichment, personalization optimization, and AI-assisted content commissioning decisions
model_cards.macro_source: 512 employment -13.91% + streaming cost control priority + AI operational adoption at 7%

structural_necessity.justification: Streaming platforms face dual pressure: content costs rising while subscriber growth slows. Studios spending 7% of operational budgets on AI (separate from 3% on production AI). Content commissioning decisions worth $100M+ each need better prediction. AI metadata enrichment and personalization are table-stakes competitive requirements.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (AI for content analytics and prediction is mature capability), F4 (streaming M&A continuing -- better tools improve acquisition targets), F5 (viewer psychology -- personalization fights churn). But operational AI is less transformative than production AI, limiting upside.

external_context.justification: Global streaming market but dominated by 5-6 major players (Netflix, Disney+, Amazon, Apple, Max, Paramount). Limited TAM (few potential customers, each very large). International market fragmented with different dynamics.

timing_grade.justification: Immediate need -- 2026 is streaming industry's 'cost control year.' Revenue within 6-9 months of deployment. But long enterprise sales cycles (6-12 months to close major streaming platform). Moderate crash resilience -- entertainment spending is discretionary.

capital_efficiency.justification: $2-5M to build platform. 75-80% gross margins. But small number of potential customers (5-10 major streaming platforms globally) means concentrated revenue risk. Each deal is large ($500K-$5M/yr) but total addressable customer count is limited.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 71.0. F1 technology force drives value. Limited TAM prevents higher score. FORCE_RIDER per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $50K-$200K/customer/year (AI inference for content analysis + recommendation optimization)
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $2M-$10M/year (internal data science teams + legacy analytics tools)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 1.5x -- better content prediction enables more commissioning decisions, expanding content library

falsification_criteria: If streaming platforms build all AI analytics internally (Netflix has strong internal capability)
If streaming industry consolidation reduces customer count below viable threshold
If content prediction accuracy does not meaningfully exceed human executive judgment
If AI-generated content makes content commissioning less important (infinite supply reduces curation value)

model_cards.model_name: Enterprise AI Search and Knowledge Infrastructure
model_cards.one_line: AI-native enterprise search and knowledge management platform replacing traditional intranets, knowledge bases, and internal search -- the 'Google replacement' for organizations
model_cards.macro_source: 519 Baumol 3.72 + AI search disrupting consumer search + enterprise parallel transformation

structural_necessity.justification: The same AI search revolution disrupting Google is coming to enterprises. Workers waste 3.6 hours/day searching for information (McKinsey). AI-native enterprise search (RAG over corporate knowledge) saves 20-40% of knowledge worker time. With 82M+ knowledge workers in US alone, the productivity gain is $500B+ annually. Every enterprise will need AI search infrastructure.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (RAG, vector databases, and LLMs enable enterprise AI search that actually works for the first time), F4 (enterprise AI $37B market growing fastest in software history). Aligned with broader 'AI replacing web search' trend. 78% enterprise AI adoption (McKinsey) creates ready market.

external_context.justification: Global enterprise need. But highly competitive market (Microsoft Copilot, Google Workspace AI, Glean, Guru, etc.). Microsoft has distribution advantage through Office 365 installed base. Differentiation requires vertical specialization or superior RAG accuracy.

timing_grade.justification: Market forming rapidly. Enterprise AI budgets allocated now. Revenue within 3-6 months for quick deployments. But Microsoft Copilot is the 800-pound gorilla -- differentiation must be clear. Crash resilient -- productivity tools maintain spend in downturns.

capital_efficiency.justification: $2-5M to MVP. 80%+ gross margins. SaaS model with $10-50/user/month pricing. Low compute costs for inference at enterprise scale. Data flywheel (more usage = better answers). Land-and-expand within enterprises.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 77.75. F1 technology force is primary driver. SN 8.5 just below STRUCTURAL_WINNER threshold. Competitive density is a concern. FORCE_RIDER per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.cost_per_unit_incumbent: $20-$100/user/month (legacy search tools + SharePoint + manual knowledge management)
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 2x -- when enterprise search actually works, employees search more (previously gave up due to poor results)

falsification_criteria: If Microsoft Copilot becomes dominant enterprise AI search (distribution advantage overwhelming)
If enterprise AI search accuracy does not significantly exceed traditional search (adoption stalls)
If data privacy concerns prevent organizations from deploying AI over internal knowledge
If market fragments into too many vertical solutions (no winner-take-most dynamics)

model_cards.model_name: AI Video Production and Post-Production Platform
model_cards.one_line: AI platform automating 60%+ of video post-production (editing, color, VFX, sound design) for mid-tier content, targeting the $15-25B post-production services market
model_cards.macro_source: 512 employment -13.91% + AI VFX/animation adoption + Hollywood restructuring

structural_necessity.justification: Studios spending <3% of production budgets on AI tools currently but 7% on operational AI. Post-production costs $5-50M per tentpole film. Mid-tier content ($1-10M budget) needs AI cost compression to remain viable. Production costs must drop 15-25% for mid-budget content survival. AI handles 60%+ of routine post-production by 2028.

force_alignment.justification: F1 (video generation/editing AI improving rapidly -- Sora, Runway, Pika), F5 (guild/union resistance creates friction but also creates demand for tools that work within union frameworks), F4 (streaming consolidation creates demand for cost-efficient content production).

external_context.justification: Global content market but Hollywood-centric for premium production. International markets (India, Nigeria, Korea) may adopt faster due to lower union resistance. Union contract negotiations in 2026 will define AI usage terms -- major uncertainty. EU AI Act implications for AI-generated content.

timing_grade.justification: Window opening but uncertain due to union negotiations (2026 contracts expire). Revenue timing depends on contract outcomes. Post-contract clarity (2027+) creates more predictable market. Moderate crash resilience -- content production is discretionary spending.

capital_efficiency.justification: $3-8M to build platform. 70-75% gross margins. GPU-intensive for video processing (higher infrastructure costs than text/code AI). But significant market size ($15-25B post-production services) provides revenue opportunity. Vertical specialization creates moat.

model_cards.category_justification: Composite 68.5 < 70.0. Model viability conditional on union contract outcomes and AI video quality reaching production standards. CONDITIONAL per hard enforcement.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $5K-$50K per project (based on production budget size) or $2K-$10K/month subscription for production studios
unit_economics.cost_per_unit_ai: $500-$5K per project (GPU compute for video processing + AI model inference)
unit_economics.break_even_volume: 50-100 mid-tier productions per year OR 100+ studio subscriptions
unit_economics.jevons_multiplier: 3x -- at 80% lower post-production costs, content volume can expand dramatically (more projects become economically viable)

falsification_criteria: If union contracts prohibit or severely restrict AI post-production tools
If AI video quality does not reach production standards for mid-tier content by 2028
If major VFX studios (ILM, Weta, Framestore) build AI tools internally rather than buy
If streaming platforms reduce content spending (shrinking the mid-tier production market)

fear_friction_assessment.analysis: The Information sector has LOWER fear friction than most sectors because its workers ARE the AI adopters. 82% of developers use AI coding tools daily. The tech workforce has the highest AI literacy and the lowest resistance to adoption. However, WITHIN the sector, fear dynamics vary dramatically by sub-sector.

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Computing Infrastructure
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: Infrastructure workers are the BUILDERS of AI. Fear runs in the opposite direction -- fear of being left behind, not fear of AI itself. Data center demand creates job security.

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Software Publishers
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: Senior developers embrace AI tools. Fear is concentrated at ENTRY LEVEL: 67% junior dev hiring collapse, 37% managers prefer AI over Gen Z. The fear is justified -- the career ladder is being shortened. K-shaped fear: seniors benefit, juniors are displaced.

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Web Search / Data Services
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: Data workers embrace AI. Search portal workers face existential threat. Fear is proportional to proximity to the 'AI replacing search' front line. Data engineers and ML engineers are fearless; SEO specialists and content strategists are terrified.

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Internet Publishing
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: Journalists and digital media workers have HIGHEST fear within NAICS 51. Washington Post layoffs (1/3 staff) make the threat concrete. But institutional resistance (editorial standards, brand trust) creates friction that SLOWS AI adoption in journalism specifically.

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Motion Picture / Entertainment
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: HIGHEST fear within NAICS 51. Union/guild structure creates institutional resistance. 52% of game devs say AI has negative impact (up from 18% two years ago). Hollywood contract negotiations in 2026 will be defined by AI fears. Fear HERE is PRODUCTIVE -- it creates regulatory moats and licensing frameworks (Suno/Udio settlements prove this).

sub_sector_fear_profiles.name: Telecom / Publishing
sub_sector_fear_profiles.notes: Telecom workers have moderate AI readiness. Long upgrade cycles (10-20 year network lifecycles) reduce urgency. Publishing workers within 513 have higher fear (see 5162 profile). Blended gap is low because telecom workforce is larger.

fear_driven_market_creation.driver: Enterprise fear that AI-generated code contains undiscovered vulnerabilities. 82% of developers using AI tools means billions of lines of unaudited AI code in production.
Fear of deepfakes (8M in 2025, 16x growth) and synthetic content (Europol 90% projection). Demand for verifiable content provenance.
Consumer willingness to pay premium for content confirmed as human-created. NYT/Bloomberg subscription model validated. Fear of misinformation drives subscriber conversion.

fear_driven_market_creation.market: AI Content Licensing and Rights Management
fear_driven_market_creation.driver: Fear of copyright infringement by AI companies. Suno/Udio settlements prove AI companies will pay for licensed data. Rights holders fear unlicensed AI training.
Union/guild fear of AI displacement creating demand for AI usage frameworks, compliance tools, and workforce transition programs within entertainment industry.

k_shaped_fear_within_sector.description: Fear within NAICS 51 follows a K-shaped pattern that mirrors the sector's economic bifurcation. Infrastructure and data workers (518, 519 data side) are confident and benefit from AI -- their skills are in higher demand and their wages are rising. Content creators (512, 5162) and entry-level tech workers are experiencing justified existential fear. This K-shape ACCELERATES the bifurcation: confident workers adopt AI faster, gaining productivity; fearful workers resist or are displaced, losing ground. The psychological divide maps directly onto the economic divide.
k_shaped_fear_within_sector.confident_cohort: Senior engineers, AI/ML specialists, data infrastructure, cloud architects, security engineers
k_shaped_fear_within_sector.fearful_cohort: Junior developers, journalists, VFX artists, content writers, SEO specialists, NOC analysts
k_shaped_fear_within_sector.productivity_gap_acceleration: The confidence gap creates a self-reinforcing productivity divergence. Confident AI adopters gain 20-40% productivity. Fearful non-adopters stagnate or decline. The gap widens by 5-10% annually through 2031.

key_findings.finding: NAICS 51 is the MOST internally bifurcated sector in the economy
key_findings.evidence: Employment ranges from +4.08% (518 infrastructure) to -13.91% (512 motion picture) within the same 2-digit NAICS. Wages range from $85K (512) to $270K (519). Baumol scores range from 1.17 to 3.72. No other sector shows this degree of internal divergence.
key_findings.implication: Treating 'Information' as a single sector is analytically wrong. The sub-sectors are moving in OPPOSITE directions. Infrastructure and content are decoupling into functionally separate economies.

key_findings.finding: The AI economy is cannibalizing its own labor force while expanding its capital base
key_findings.evidence: NAICS 51 employment -2.33% while sector revenue grows. $700B combined hyperscaler capex in 2026. Entry-level hiring -67% in software. Motion picture -14% to -24%. Capital is REPLACING labor at the sector level, not augmenting it.
key_findings.implication: The Information sector provides a 2-3 year preview of what will happen in other cognitive sectors (finance, professional services, education). Capital-labor substitution is happening FIRST in the sector that builds the tools.

key_findings.finding: The Solow Paradox is deeper in NAICS 51 than in any other sector
key_findings.evidence: 82% of developers use AI tools daily. 25-40% of Google code is AI-generated. But experienced devs are 19% SLOWER on complex tasks with AI. Enterprise-wide EBIT impact from AI remains 'rare' despite $37B spending. The sector investing most in AI is ALSO the sector where AI productivity paradox is most visible.
key_findings.implication: AI productivity gains are real for ROUTINE-COGNITIVE tasks (code completion, content generation) but negative for TACIT-COGNITIVE tasks (architecture, creative direction, complex debugging). This validates the Barbell Economy thesis: the middle gets automated, the top gets harder.

key_findings.finding: P-037 Entry-Level Extinction has its EPICENTER in NAICS 51
key_findings.evidence: 67% junior developer hiring collapse. 37% managers prefer AI over Gen Z hire. 74% of game industry students concerned about job prospects. The sector that trained the world's software engineers is no longer hiring them at entry level.
key_findings.implication: By 2031, the information sector faces an acute mid-career talent shortage. The pipeline that produces senior architects and creative directors runs through entry-level roles that no longer exist. This is a 5-year time bomb: the sector is consuming its own future workforce.

key_findings.finding: Physical constraints on AI infrastructure are the BINDING LIMIT on Information sector transformation
key_findings.evidence: P-038: Data center occupancy 95%+ by late 2026. Grid queue 2,600 GW, 5+ year wait. PJM auction $16.4B (3rd record). Copper deficit 766K tonnes by 2030. Water stress 1.7B gal/day. The AI revolution's speed is limited by electrons, not algorithms.
key_findings.implication: Infrastructure (NAICS 518) is the sector's STRATEGIC BOTTLENECK. Every model card in this analysis is ultimately constrained by compute availability. This makes infrastructure optimization (MC-INFO-001) the highest-leverage opportunity.

key_findings.finding: Fear friction INVERTS within NAICS 51 -- the sector is simultaneously the most AI-confident AND most AI-fearful
key_findings.evidence: Zero friction in infrastructure (518). High friction in entertainment (512, gap 4) and journalism (5162, gap 4). K-shaped: infrastructure workers embrace AI, content workers fear it. 52% of game devs say negative impact (up from 18% in 2 years). But 82% of software devs use AI daily.
key_findings.implication: Fear friction within a sector can vary by 4+ points across sub-sectors. Sector-level fear friction scores are misleading. Sub-sector analysis is required for accurate transformation timing projections.

key_findings.finding: The Information sector's transformation creates $500B+ in second-order cascade effects across the economy
key_findings.evidence: Professional services cascade ($100B+ IT consulting disruption), education pipeline collapse (CS enrollment decline), CRE double hit (tech office vacancy), advertising restructuring ($740B digital ad market), energy grid transformation (945 TWh by 2030), creative economy restructuring ($500B+ reallocation), and AI safety market creation ($86B by 2030).
key_findings.implication: NAICS 51's transformation is not contained within the sector. It is the PRIMARY transmission mechanism for AI disruption to reach every other sector of the economy. Understanding Information sector dynamics is prerequisite for understanding any other sector's transformation path.

key_findings.finding: Model card scoring reveals a 14-point spread between infrastructure and content opportunities
key_findings.evidence: MC-INFO-002 (AI Code Security) scored 82.5 (STRUCTURAL_WINNER). MC-INFO-010 (AI Video Production) scored 68.5 (CONDITIONAL). The spread reflects the fundamental bifurcation: infrastructure/security/data opportunities score 76-82; content/media opportunities score 68-71.
key_findings.implication: Capital should flow to infrastructure-layer opportunities within NAICS 51, not content-layer opportunities. The Barbell Economy creates premium returns at the infrastructure substrate and the creative pinnacle, with diminishing returns in the automated middle.

top_3.name: AI Code Quality and Security Audit Platform

model_card_summary.notes: 10 model cards constructed. 1 STRUCTURAL_WINNER (AI code security -- structural necessity as 82% of devs use AI tools). 6 FORCE_RIDERS spanning infrastructure, telecom, software M&A, data licensing, enterprise search, and streaming intelligence. 1 FEAR_ECONOMY card (content authentication -- demand created by synthetic content fear). 2 CONDITIONAL cards (investigative journalism and AI video production -- both dependent on external factors: subscriber willingness and union contract outcomes).

sector_transformation_update.evidence_summary: v3-6 deep dive: 10 model cards scored (mean 76.25, range 68.5-82.5). Internal bifurcation confirmed and quantified: infrastructure (518) growing +4.08% while content (512) collapsing -13.91%. Software publishing (5132) faces existential pressure from 82% AI coding adoption + 67% junior hiring collapse. Baumol scores range 1.17-3.72 within sector. K-shaped fear friction (gap 0 to 4 within sub-sectors). $500B+ second-order cascade effects identified. Entry-level extinction (P-037) has epicenter in NAICS 51.

fear_friction_update.notes: UPDATED from simple 'low friction' to 'low friction aggregate BUT K-shaped.' Sub-sector gaps range from 0 (infrastructure) to 4 (entertainment, journalism). Aggregate gap of 2 is misleading -- must analyze at sub-sector level.

new_pattern_candidates.description: Information Sector Self-Cannibalization: The sector building AI tools is the first sector disrupted by them. Capital-labor substitution happening at the source. Employment -2.33% while revenue grows. Entry-level pipeline destruction. This is NOT analogous to any other sector's AI transformation because the sector IS the transformation.
new_pattern_candidates.evidence: NAICS 51 employment -2.33% while sector revenue grows. 82% AI coding adoption. 67% junior hiring collapse. $700B hyperscaler capex. Motion picture -14% to -24%. The sector producing AI tools is consuming its own workforce.

new_pattern_candidates.description: Baumol Destruction vs Baumol Cure Divergence: Some sectors experience AI as Baumol Cure (cost compression releasing stored energy in healthcare, legal, education). Information sector content sub-sectors experience AI as Baumol Destruction (both costs AND revenues collapse simultaneously). This is a fundamentally different dynamic requiring different model archetypes.
new_pattern_candidates.evidence: Internet publishing (5162): employment -6.36%, wages +16.4%, BUT revenue model (ad-supported web traffic) collapsing from AI search. Motion picture (512): employment -14%, wages flat, revenue model threatened by AI content generation. In both cases, AI does not 'cure' cost disease -- it destroys the economic foundation.
